The sixth grade class is taught by Mrs. Haley Roach.

RAINBOW LAB
Parke Heritage Middle School science students have been reviewing scientific units and measurement. For this lab, they had to collaborate, plan, think critically, use graduated cylinders and pipettes, make observations, and record their data. Their task was to create a rainbow of 25 mL solutions, but they were only given solutions of primary colors. They had to mix solutions in various ratios of their choosing, and pick the "best" secondary color formulas. Once they had their favorite orange, purple, and green, they arranged their colors into a rainbow. A few groups got to create their own "designer colors" by making unique solutions from their rainbow.

We must make sure that every Hoosier child counts in the 2020 Census!

Phone Numbers and Emergency Contacts need to be kept up-to-date so if the need arises for a student to be sent home they can be picked up in a timely manner.
Students will not be allowed to come into school late. If a student is not feeling well, has an appointment, etc they will need to stay home the entire day.

Upon his retirement, he plans to mow 13 yards, go fishing and spend time with his two grandsons, Jackson and Elliot Wrightsman. In addition to his grandsons, other family members are his wife, Jean; son, Junior and daughter, Lisa and her husband, Roy.
“It’s been a blast being here,” said Rick. “I’ve enjoyed it, and I’ve met a lot of friends. It’s been a nice place to work.”
NCP staff and students wish you well, Rick, and hope you enjoy your retirement.

Congrats to Parke Heritage senior Kara Hayes on earning this scholarship!

Selected through a competitive process based on academic achievement and other factors, recipients will receive $7,500
annually (up to $30,000 total) for committing to teach in Indiana for at least five years after graduating college.
“Congratulations to all 200 students, who are on their way to becoming impactful, future Hoosier teachers,” said Indiana
Commissioner for Higher Education Teresa Lubbers. “We know these students have the passion and determination to
make a difference in classrooms across the state.”

A total of 367 students applied for the 2020-21 Next Generation Hoosier Educators Scholarship, with applications from 213 high schools in 82 of Indiana’s 92 counties. Over 83% of applicants were Indiana high school seniors with the
remainder comprised of current college students.
To qualify for the scholarship, students had to either graduate in the highest 20 percent of their high school class or earn a score in the top 20th percentile on the SAT or ACT.
